docs.lead_paragraph: PAULINE PELLEGRINO was expecting a big baby. Ms. Pellegrino, a 37-year-old Leonia resident, said her doctor had estimated that her baby would weigh about 9 pounds. It was the day before Ms. Pellegrino's due date, and the baby showed no sign of being born soon. Big babies can often mean difficult deliveries and possible injury to both mother and child, so her doctor decided to try to induce labor with the drug Pitocin. It wasn't effective, so the dosage was increased, but then the baby's heartbeat became irregular; Ms. Pellegrino was then wheeled into the Englewood Hospital operating room for a swift Caesarean section. Her daughter weighed a normal 7 pounds 10 ounces.

headline.main: Not-So-Special Delivery: State Leads in C-Sections

docs.abstract: Article on high number of caesarean sections in New Jersey; preliminary data from National Center for Health Statistics show that New Jersey topped country in 2003 at 33.1 percent compared with 27.6 percent nationwide; reasons why C-sections are on rise in state include large population of older mothers who tend to have more risk factors during pregnancy, growing number of women who opt for C-sections for sake of convenience and skyrocketing cost of malpractice liability insurance for obstetricians; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the Democratic Party's search for a middle ground on abortion referred incorrectly to the position of Naral Pro-Choice, the abortion-rights group, on the Unborn Child Pain Awareness Act, which would require doctors to offer anesthetic for the fetuses of women seeking abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy. The organization only recently took a stand, deciding not to oppose the legislation; it did not reverse course and drop its objections.

docs.lead_paragraph: The State Supreme Court has ruled unanimously that a woman whose daughter was stillborn as a result of medical malpractice can sue for emotional distress. State law generally does not allow damages for the emotional distress of bystanders, and an appeals court had upheld a dismissal of the personal injury claim by the woman, Bonnie Pierce of Outagamie County. In the Supreme Court ruling, though, Justice David T. Prosser wrote, ''We cannot separate the damages Pierce suffered into what could be described as 'her own' from those she suffered in experiencing the stillbirth of her daughter.'' Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Injury Claim Can Go Forward

docs.abstract: Wisconsin Supreme Court rules that Bonnie Pierce, whose daughter was stillborn as result of medical malpractice, can sue for emotional distress (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the last six years, Working Mother magazine listed Novartis, the pharmaceutical manufacturer, as among the best 100 companies for women, citing its generous maternity leave and a program to encourage telecommuting from home. But a dozen women sales representatives for Novartis beg to differ. In a lawsuit filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the women contend that they were discriminated against in pay and promotions, particularly after becoming pregnant. The company's products include the Gerber baby brands.

headline.main: 12 Women File Bias Suit Against Large Drug Maker

docs.abstract: Twelve women sales representative for Novartis file suit against drug maker contending that they were discriminated against in pay and promotions, particularly after becoming pregnant (M)
docs.snippet: For the last six years, Working Mother magazine listed Novartis, the pharmaceutical manufacturer, as among the best 100 companies for women, citing its generous maternity leave and a program to encourage telecommuting from home.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Having read ''Bush's Sex Scandal,'' we beg to disagree. My wife (a pediatrician) and I (a family physician) agree wholeheartedly with President Bush about abstinence-only. And quoting anything from the Alan Guttmacher Institute and Planned Parenthood is tainted, given that they make a living off promoting contraception and abortion.

headline.main: Abstinence and the Sex Ed Debate

docs.abstract: Dr Dave McCann letter notes that he and his wife, a pediatrician, agree wholeheartedly with Pres Bush about abstinence-only (Nicholas Kristof's Feb 16 column)

docs.lead_paragraph: Inverness Medical Innovations, Waltham, Mass., which makes home pregnancy tests, said it agreed to buy Ischemia Technologies, Denver, which makes a cardiac diagnostic test, for about $22.4 million in stock. Primedia, New York, the magazine publisher, said it would buy Atlanta Cars Magazine. Terms were not disclosed. Hanover Direct, Edgewater, N.J., which sells merchandise through catalogs, agreed to sell Gump's, a department store in San Francisco, to a group of private investors. Terms were not disclosed. Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, a maker of chemicals for research laboratories, will purchase Proligo Group, Boulder, Colo., which supplies research tools for the synthesis of genetic material. Terms were not disclosed.
docs.snippet: Inverness Medical Innovations, Waltham, Mass., which makes home pregnancy tests, said it agreed to buy Ischemia Technologies, Denver, which makes a cardiac diagnostic test, for about $22.4 million in stock.    Primedia, New York, the magazine...

docs.lead_paragraph: Women in labor may suffer needlessly because doctors mistakenly advise them to delay a common pain treatment for fear that it will impede contractions and lead to a Caesarean section, researchers are reporting. A new study of the treatment -- a type of anesthesia that injects painkiller into the spinal fluid and the epidural area around the spinal cord to numb the pelvic region -- finds that giving it early or late in labor makes no difference in Caesarean rates among women having first babies.

headline.main: Study Urges Early Pain Drug In Labor for First Deliveries

docs.abstract: Study by anesthesiologist Dr Cynthia A Wong says women in labor may suffer needlessly because doctors advise them to delay common pain treatment for fear that it will impede contractions and lead to Caesarean section; finds that treatment, epidural anesthesia, makes no difference in Caesarean rates among women having first babies; other researchers urge caution; findings are published in New England Journal of Medicine (M)
docs.snippet: Doctors mistakenly advise women in labor to delay a common pain treatment for fear that it will impede contractions and lead to a Caesarean section, researchers report.

docs.lead_paragraph: The warning hanging above a main street could not have been more blunt, its big white characters set off against a bright red banner promising to ''firmly crack down on the criminal activity of drowning and other ways of brutally killing female babies.'' Just across the way, though, in equally large letters, the advertisement above a medical clinic promoted ultrasound tests, which have long been used in China to detect the sex of babies, as a prelude to aborting female fetuses. ''I don't know what happens elsewhere, but we don't do gender tests here,'' said a 48-year-old doctor who gave her name only as Li. ''Our equipment can't detect the sex before six months. The machine is too small.''

headline.main: As Girls 'Vanish,' Chinese City Battles Tide of Abortions

docs.abstract: City of Guiyang, China, has enacted pioneering ban on abortions after 1th week of pregnancy, part of campaign to address one of world's biggest gaps between male and female childbirths; national laws already prohibit sonograms for gender detection, but law has been spottily enforced; experience of Giuyang reveals how difficult task China faces in trying to fine-tune its 25-year-old 'one-child policy,' one of most ambitious social engineering measures ever attempted; policy has been great success at meeting goal of slowing country's population, but Chinese planners underestimated urge of couples to have sons; result has been large-scale abortion of female fetuses and routine killing or abandoment of baby girls; photos (M)
docs.snippet: China under a "one-child policy" may have underestimated the desire for a boy.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Democrats Getting Lessons in Speaking Their Values'' (Congressional Memo, Feb. 11):
docs.abstract: Letter from Joan Malin (Planned Parenthood of New York City) holds it is troubling to see false dichotomy emerge between those who see abortion and same-sex marriage as divisive 'below the waist' issues and those who see them as fundamental to living in a free and fair society (Feb 11 article)
